conclusion: The v-t graph represents velocity (v) on the y-axis in m·s⁻¹ versus time (t) on the x-axis in seconds. The velocity values indicate the particle's motion direction.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at +2 m·s⁻¹.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from +2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.

Positive velocity (+v) indicates motion in the defined positive direction, negative velocity (-v) indicates motion opposite to the defined positive direction, and zero velocity indicates the particle is momentarily at rest.

premise: From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.
conclusion: At t = 2s, the velocity is 0 m·s⁻¹, and at t = 3s, the velocity is -2 m·s⁻¹.

premise: From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.
conclusion: Throughout the interval from 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity is negative and decreasing (becoming more negative).

premise: Negative velocity indicates motion opposite to the defined positive direction. From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity is consistently negative.
conclusion: From 2 to 3 seconds, the particle moves in the direction opposite to the defined positive direction.
